message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Artificial life: The coming evolution
Paper Abstract: Within fifty to a hundred years a new class of organisms is likely to emerge. These organisms will be artificial in the sense that they will originally be designed by humans. However, they will reproduce, and will evolve into something other than their initial form; they will be alive'' under any reasonable definition of the word. These organisms will evolve in a fundamentally different manner than contemporary biological organisms, since their reproduction will be under at least partial conscious control, giving it a Lamarckian component. The pace of evolutionary change consequently will be extremely rapid. The advent of artificial life will be the most significant historical event since the emergence of human beings. The impact on humanity and the biosphere could be enormous, larger than the industrial revolution, nuclear weapons, or environmental pollution. We must take steps now to shape the emergence of artificial organisms; they have potential to be either the ugliest terrestrial disaster, or the most beautiful creation of humanity. 22 refs., 3 figs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Biology of Reproduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biology_of_Reproduction"},{"title":"Reproduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproduction"},{"title":"Reproductive biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproductive_biology"},{"title":"Sexual reproduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_reproduction"},{"title":"Human reproductive ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_reproductive_ecology"},{"title":"Systems Biology in Reproductive Medicine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_Biology_in_Reproductive_Medicine"},{"title":"Human reproduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_reproduction"},{"title":"Cost of reproduction hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_of_reproduction_hypothesis"},{"title":"Natural selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_selection"},{"title":"Altruism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altruism_(biology)#:~:text=So by behaving altruistically, an,behavior, such as reciprocal altruism."}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of reproduction biology:

## Definition

Reproduction (or procreation or breeding) is the biological process by which new individual organisms – "offspring" – are produced from their "parent" or parents.

## Types of Reproduction

Reproductive biology includes both sexual and asexual reproduction. 

**Asexual Reproduction:** In asexual reproduction, an organism can reproduce without the involvement of another organism.(no content)By asexual reproduction, an organism creates a genetically similar or identical copy of itself.

**Sexual Reproduction:** Sexual reproduction is a biological process that creates a new organism by combining the genetic material of two organisms in a process that starts with meiosis, a specialized type of cell division.(no content)Sexual reproduction is the most common life cycle in multicellular eukaryotes, such as animals, fungi and plants.

## Human Reproduction

Human reproductive biology is primarily controlled through hormones, which send signals to the human reproductive structures to influence growth and maturation.(no content)Estrogen is one of the sexual reproductive hormones that aid in the sexual reproductive system of the female.(no content)Testosterone, an androgen, although present in both males and females, is relatively more abundant in males and serves as one of the major sexual reproductive hormones in the male reproductive system.

This field encompasses many interdisciplinary approaches to understanding how organisms create and develop new life.

Links: [{"title":"Industrial Revolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution"},{"title":"Second Industrial Revolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_Industrial_Revolution"},{"title":"Industrial Revolution in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Fourth Industrial Revolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourth_Industrial_Revolution"},{"title":"The Third Industrial Revolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Third_Industrial_Revolution"},{"title":"What the Industrial Revolution Did for Us - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/What_the_Industrial_Revolution_Did_for_Us"},{"title":"The New Left: The Anti-Industrial Revolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_Left:_The_Anti-Industrial_Revolution"},{"title":"Steam power during the Industrial Revolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steam_power_during_the_Industrial_Revolution"},{"title":"Industrial revolutions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_revolutions"},{"title":"Third Industrial Revolution (Information Age) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_Industrial_Revolution_(Information_Age)"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of the Industrial Revolution based on the search results:

## Definition and Overview

The Industrial Revolution was a transitional period of the global economy toward more widespread, efficient and stable manufacturing processes, succeeding the Second Agricultural Revolution.(no content)Economic historians agree that the onset of the Industrial Revolution is the most important event in human history, comparable only to the adoption of agriculture with respect to material advancement.

## Timeline and Phases

The precise start and end of the Industrial Revolution is debated among historians. Eric Hobsbawm held that the Industrial Revolution began in Britain in the 1780s and was not fully felt until the 1830s, while T. S. Ashton held that it occurred between 1760 and 1830.(no content)The Industrial Revolution is sometimes divided into the First Industrial Revolution and Second Industrial Revolution.(no content)The Second Industrial Revolution, also known as the Technological Revolution, was a phase of rapid scientific discovery, standardisation, mass production and industrialisation from the late 19th century into the early 20th century.

## Key Characteristics and Innovations

The First Industrial Revolution was marked by a transition from hand production methods to machines through the use of steam power and water power. Its effects had consequences on textile manufacturing, which was first to adopt such changes, as well as iron industry, agriculture, and mining.(no content)The core of the Industrial Revolution was the generation and distribution of energy from coal and water to produce steam and, later in the 20th century, electricity.

## Social and Economic Impact

Average income and population began to exhibit unprecedented sustained growth. Economists note the most important effect was that the standard of living for most in the Western world began to increase consistently for the first time.

Links: [{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Convergent evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_evolution"},{"title":"Differential evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_evolution"},{"title":"Evolution (2015 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_(2015_film)"},{"title":"Human evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_evolution"},{"title":"WWE Evolution (2025) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_Evolution_(2025)"},{"title":"Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_Lancer_Evolution"},{"title":"Evolution (2001 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_(2001_film)"},{"title":"GE Evolution Series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GE_Evolution_Series"},{"title":"Stellar evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_evolution"}]

I've performed a web search for "Evolution" and retrieved comprehensive results covering multiple meanings of the term:

## Biological Evolution

Evolution is the change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations.(no content)It occurs when evolutionary processes such as genetic drift and natural selection act on genetic variation, resulting in certain characteristics becoming more or less common within populations.(no content)Evolution by natural selection is established by observable facts about living organisms: more offspring are often produced than can possibly survive; traits vary among individuals with respect to their morphology, physiology, and behaviour; different traits confer different rates of survival and reproduction; and traits can be passed from generation to generation.

## Related Concepts

- **Human Evolution**: Over their evolutionary history, humans gradually developed traits such as bipedalism, dexterity, and complex language.

- **Convergent Evolution**: Convergent evolution is the independent evolution of similar features in species of different lineages. Convergent evolution creates analogous structures that have similar form or function but were not present in the last common ancestor of those groups.

- **Stellar Evolution**: Stellar evolution is the process by which a star changes over the course of time.

## Other Uses

The search also returned results for other meanings of "Evolution," including a 2001 science fiction film, a 2025 WWE women's wrestling event, a Mitsubishi automobile model, a differential evolution algorithm, and GE Evolution Series diesel locomotives.

I've performed a web search for "Evolution" and retrieved comprehensive results covering multiple meanings of the term:

## Biological Evolution

Evolution is the change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations.(no content)It occurs when evolutionary processes such as genetic drift and natural selection act on genetic variation, resulting in certain characteristics becoming more or less common within populations.(no content)Evolution by natural selection is established by observable facts about living organisms: more offspring are often produced than can possibly survive; traits vary among individuals with respect to their morphology, physiology, and behaviour; different traits confer different rates of survival and reproduction; and traits can be passed from generation to generation.

## Related Concepts

- **Human Evolution**: Over their evolutionary history, humans gradually developed traits such as bipedalism, dexterity, and complex language.

- **Convergent Evolution**: Convergent evolution is the independent evolution of similar features in species of different lineages. Convergent evolution creates analogous structures that have similar form or function but were not present in the last common ancestor of those groups.

- **Stellar Evolution**: Stellar evolution is the process by which a star changes over the course of time.

## Other Uses

The search also returned results for other meanings of "Evolution," including a 2001 science fiction film, a 2025 WWE women's wrestling event, a Mitsubishi automobile model, a differential evolution algorithm, and GE Evolution Series diesel locomotives.

Web search results for query: "Lamarckism"

Links: [{"title":"Lamarckism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lamarckism"},{"title":"Jean-Baptiste Lamarck - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Lamarck"},{"title":"Category:Critics of Lamarckism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Critics_of_Lamarckism"},{"title":"Category:Lamarckism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Lamarckism"},{"title":"Ernst Haeckel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Haeckel"},{"title":"Sir Richard Vyvyan, 8th Baronet - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sir_Richard_Vyvyan,_8th_Baronet"},{"title":"Talk:Back to Methuselah - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Back_to_Methuselah"},{"title":"Poisson distribution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poisson_probability"}]

## Lamarckism

Lamarckism, also known as Lamarckian inheritance or neo-Lamarckism, is the notion that an organism can pass on to its offspring physical characteristics that the parent organism acquired through use or disuse during its lifetime.

### Historical Background

The inheritance of acquired characteristics was proposed in ancient times and remained a current idea for many centuries, with the belief having been generally accepted for at least 2,200 years before Lamarck's time.(no content)The modern era generally remembers Lamarck for this theory, which he described in his 1809 Philosophie zoologique.

### Key Concepts

Lamarck theorized that individuals lose characteristics they do not require, or use, and develop characteristics that are useful, and argued that the acquired traits were heritable.(no content)He gave as an imagined illustration the idea that when giraffes stretch their necks to reach leaves high in trees, they would strengthen and gradually lengthen their necks, and these giraffes would then have offspring with slightly longer necks.

### Scientific Status

Mendelian genetics supplanted the notion of inheritance of acquired traits, eventually leading to the development of the modern synthesis, and the general abandonment of Lamarckism in biology. However, in the 21st century, experimental results in the fields of epigenetics, genetics, and somatic hypermutation demonstrated the possibility of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance of traits acquired by the previous generation, proving a limited validity of Lamarckism.

Web search results for query: "Artificial life"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_life"},{"title":"History of artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_life"},{"title":"Artificial Life (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Life_(journal)"},{"title":"Category:Artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Artificial_life"},{"title":"Artificial creation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_creation"},{"title":"Christopher Langton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Langton"},{"title":"Artificial chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_chemistry"},{"title":"Avida - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avida"},{"title":"Max Tegmark - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Tegmark"},{"title":"Category:Artificial life models - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Artificial_life_models"}]

Here are the search results for "Artificial life":

## Overview

Artificial Life (ALife) is a field of study wherein researchers examine systems related to natural life, its processes, and its evolution, through the use of simulations with computer models, robotics, and biochemistry.

## History and Key Figures

The discipline was named by Christopher Langton, an American computer scientist, in 1986.(no content)In 1987, Langton organized the first conference on the field, in Los Alamos, New Mexico.

## Main Approaches

There are three main kinds of alife, named for their approaches: soft, from software; hard, from hardware; and wet, from biochemistry.

## Research Focus

Artificial life studies the fundamental processes of living systems in artificial environments in order to gain a deeper understanding of the complex information processing that define such systems.(no content)The modeling philosophy of artificial life strongly differs from traditional modeling by studying not only "life as we know it" but also "life as it could be".

## Philosophical Perspectives

There are differing opinions about whether artificial systems constitute actual life. At present, the commonly accepted definition of life does not consider any current alife simulations or software to be alive, and they do not constitute part of the evolutionary process of any ecosystem. However, the strong alife position states that "life is a process which can be abstracted away from any particular medium" and notably, Tom Ray declared that his program Tierra is not simulating life in a computer but synthesizing it.

Web search results for query: "Environmental pollution"

Links: [{"title":"Pollution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pollution"},{"title":"Environmental Pollution (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_Pollution_(journal)"},{"title":"Air pollution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_pollution"},{"title":"British environmental law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_environmental_law"},{"title":"Environmental impact of paint - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_impact_of_paint"},{"title":"Environmental issues in Bangladesh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Bangladesh"},{"title":"Water pollution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Water_pollution"},{"title":"Health and environmental effects of transport - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Health_and_environmental_effects_of_transport"},{"title":"Environmental issues in Tehran - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Tehran"},{"title":"Plastic pollution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plastic_pollution"}]

Here are the search results for "Environmental pollution":

## Definition and Overview

Pollution is the introduction of contaminants into the natural environment that cause harm.(no content)Pollution can take the form of any substance (solid, liquid, or gas) or energy (such as radioactivity, heat, sound, or light).(no content)Although environmental pollution can be caused by natural events, the word pollution generally implies that the contaminants have a human source, such as manufacturing, extractive industries, poor waste management, transportation or agriculture.

## Impact on Health and Society

Pollution has widespread consequences on human and environmental health, having systematic impact on social and economic systems. In 2019, pollution killed approximately nine million people worldwide (about one in six deaths that year); about three-quarters of these deaths were caused by air pollution.

## Major Forms of Pollution

The main types of environmental pollution include:

- **Air Pollution**: The release of chemicals and particulates into the atmosphere. Common gaseous pollutants include carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and nitrogen oxides produced by industry and motor vehicles.

- **Plastic Pollution**: Plastic pollution involves the accumulation of plastic products and microplastics in the environment that adversely affects wildlife, wildlife habitat, or humans.

- **Water Pollution**: Marine pollution occurs when substances used or spread by humans, such as industrial, agricultural, and residential waste; particles; noise; excess carbon dioxide; or invasive organisms enter the ocean and cause harmful effects. The majority of this waste (80%) comes from land-based activity.

- **Soil Contamination**: Soil contamination occurs when chemicals are released by spill or underground leakage. Among the most significant soil contaminants are hydrocarbons, heavy metals, MTBE, herbicides, pesticides and chlorinated hydrocarbons.

- **Soil Contamination**: Soil contamination occurs when chemicals are released by spill or underground leakage. Among the most significant soil contaminants are hydrocarbons, heavy metals, MTBE, herbicides, pesticides and chlorinated hydrocarbons.

Here are the search results for "Environmental pollution":

## Definition and Overview

Pollution is the introduction of contaminants into the natural environment that cause harm.(no content)Pollution can take the form of any substance (solid, liquid, or gas) or energy (such as radioactivity, heat, sound, or light).(no content)Although environmental pollution can be caused by natural events, the word pollution generally implies that the contaminants have a human source, such as manufacturing, extractive industries, poor waste management, transportation or agriculture.

## Impact on Health and Society

Pollution has widespread consequences on human and environmental health, having systematic impact on social and economic systems. In 2019, pollution killed approximately nine million people worldwide (about one in six deaths that year); about three-quarters of these deaths were caused by air pollution.

## Major Forms of Pollution

The main types of environmental pollution include:

- **Air Pollution**: The release of chemicals and particulates into the atmosphere. Common gaseous pollutants include carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and nitrogen oxides produced by industry and motor vehicles.

- **Plastic Pollution**: Plastic pollution involves the accumulation of plastic products and microplastics in the environment that adversely affects wildlife, wildlife habitat, or humans.

- **Water Pollution**: Marine pollution occurs when substances used or spread by humans, such as industrial, agricultural, and residential waste; particles; noise; excess carbon dioxide; or invasive organisms enter the ocean and cause harmful effects. The majority of this waste (80%) comes from land-based activity.

- **Soil Contamination**: Soil contamination occurs when chemicals are released by spill or underground leakage. Among the most significant soil contaminants are hydrocarbons, heavy metals, MTBE, herbicides, pesticides and chlorinated hydrocarbons.

Web search results for query: "Nuclear weapons"

Links: [{"title":"Nuclear weapon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapon"},{"title":"List of states with nuclear weapons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons"},{"title":"Nuclear weapons of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"History of nuclear weapons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_nuclear_weapons"},{"title":"Nuclear warfare - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_warfare"},{"title":"List of nuclear weapons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nuclear_weapons"},{"title":"Timeline of nuclear weapons development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_nuclear_weapons_development"},{"title":"Nuclear weapon design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_weapon_design"},{"title":"United States and weapons of mass destruction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction"},{"title":"Nuclear proliferation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_proliferation"}]

I've completed the web search for "Nuclear weapons". Here's a comprehensive summary of the key information found:

## Definition and Basic Characteristics

A nuclear weapon is an explosive device that derives its destructive force from nuclear reactions, either nuclear fission (fission or atomic bomb) or a combination of fission and nuclear fusion reactions (thermonuclear weapon), producing a nuclear explosion.(no content)Both bomb types release large quantities of energy from relatively small amounts of matter.

## Destructive Power and Effects

Nuclear weapons have had yields between 10 tons (the W54) and 50 megatons for the Tsar Bomba, and yields in the low kilotons can devastate cities.(no content)Apart from the blast, effects of nuclear weapons include extreme heat and ionizing radiation, firestorms, radioactive nuclear fallout, an electromagnetic pulse, and a radar blackout.

## Historical Development and Use

The first nuclear weapons were developed by the United States in collaboration with the United Kingdom and Canada during World War II in the Manhattan Project.(no content)Nuclear weapons have been used twice in war, in the 1945 atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki that killed between 150,000 and 246,000 people.

## Nuclear Powers and Arsenals

There are currently nine sovereign states that are generally understood to possess nuclear weapons, though only eight formally acknowledge possessing them.(no content)According to the Federation of American Scientists (FAS), there are 12,331 nuclear warheads in the world and approximately 3,904 of these are active, as of 2025.

## International Control and Prevention

Nuclear weapons are weapons of mass destruction, and their control is a focus of international security through measures to prevent nuclear proliferation, arms control, or nuclear disarmament.

message_text:
Excellent! I have successfully completed the entity extraction and validation for the paper "Artificial life: The coming evolution". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification**: Survey

**Extracted Triples (7 total)**:
1. **Artificial life** - concept - The paper discusses the future emergence of artificial organisms based on this field of research
2. **Reproduction** - concept - Fundamental to the paper's definition of living organisms
3. **Evolution** - concept - Central to discussing how artificial organisms will change over time
4. **Lamarckism** - concept - Explicitly mentioned as the Lamarckian component of artificial life evolution
5. **Industrial Revolution** - concept - Used as a historical comparison for impact magnitude
6. **Nuclear weapon** - artifact - Referenced for comparative impact assessment
7. **Pollution** - concept - Environmental pollution mentioned for scale comparison

**Validation**: ✅ Passed all checks
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid
- Entity types properly categorized (6 concepts, 1 artifact)
- All required fields populated (name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance)
- Validation requirements met: minimum 1 "uses" relation and paper_type properly set

The triples_output.json file has been successfully updated and validated.

Sources:
- [Artificial life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_life)
- [Reproduction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reproduction)
- [Evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution)
- [Lamarckism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lamarckism)
- [Industrial Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution)
